bibl.title: Letter from M.A. Barber to Laura Armistead Carter, May 16, 1929

div1.p: Barber sends Laura Carter material by her father on the history of malaria in Virginia, asking if he may use it in an article. He informs her that he will leave the Public Health Service to work for the International Health Board in Africa.

div1.head: Letter from M.A. Barber to Laura Armistead Carter, May 16, 1929
div1.opener:
Malaria
Barber
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
P.O. Box 146, Greenwood, Miss. May 16, 1929.
Dear Miss Carter:
div1.p:
I am trying this spring to get together something on the
history of malaria in the U.S., just a short article-with a moral, if
I can think of one. You were kind enough in 1925 to send me in 1925
a letter from your father giving some very valuable data on the early
history of malaria in Virginia and elsewhere. I should much like to
include some of this material, the more the better. but I do not
want to put anything in that you might not approve of. I enclose
a copy of the things I would wish to include. Please tell me if
it will be all right to use these. Edit them if you choose, but
I hope you will not leave out much. I may put in one or two other
paragraphs, but these would be all right I know, just purely scientific
material. I want to quote as much as I can.

I had planned to write a paper on this subject for the International
Congress at Rome, 1925 but Dr. Fricks thought that the other subject
which I finally chose for that meeting would be more suitable,
anyhow more interesting to the crowned heads of science over there.

I am about to leave the Service to do research work yellow fever West
Africa, Rockefeller Commission, Yaba near Lagos, Nigeria. I leave next month
for Liverpool. I wish I had only a fraction of the knowledge your father had
on the subject.
